div.p: LEISUREANDSOCIETY is one of the 16 major DIV1 content elements within BIOGRAPHY sections of entries defined as integral to mapping a woman's life. It captures information concerning the cultural and social activities of a person, including hobbies, sporting life and non-literary cultural or social life. Individual friendships should be captured under FRIENDSASSOCIATES and volunteer philanthropic activities should be captured under OCCUPATION but her hosting a literary salon, or notable bakery, can be entered here. For the purposes of this Project, we are not defining leisure as what she does with her free time because this assumes a gendered and classed notion of labour. Society in this context refers to the larger community and her social life within it, not primarily to an elite, fashionable social circle - but things like being presented at court or having her portrait painted do figure here. This tag has no content sub-elements or attributes.

div.codeblock: MB made her debut at a ball in Brighton.
BC's diverse projects have included designing wallpaper and home furnishings.

Olympic Sailor1924EKM sailed in the Paris Olympics. She was the only woman representing Switzerland.

Later, she was one of an all-woman crew on a voyage from France to Greece.

For fifteen years, SM held Ireland's only literary salons at her home in Kildare Street. She concentrated on entertaining -- singing, playing the harp, and reciting -- and social events, rather than writing.

div.p: Because of the broad-ranging information captured within LEISUREANDSOCIETY, try to include in your prose words that may help in searching. For instance, the word sport would be useful in the EKM example above. Consider including here:

ul.li: dress (includes: fashion, for example, Amelia Bloomer or Nancy Cunard’s bracelets; does not include needlepoint or dress design which would be creative activity under OCCUPATION.)

cooking/food/drink, painting, sculpting, amateur acting, photography, gardening, playing instruments, needlework, crafts. Note: First consider whether such activities fall under OCCUPATION: SIGNIFICANTACTIVITY before including here.)
groups (includes: activities involving loosely-organized or loosely-defined groups, e.g. ran a salon, ran the local Women’s Institute)
patronage activities (giving not receiving as an author)
personal transport (walking, biking, driving horses, cars, planes.)

div.p: Question: If she exhibited her artwork at a gallery and it is unclear whether or not she made money as an artist, is this LeisureAndSociety (using potential search terms like creative activity, painting, etc., ) or a SIGNIFICANTACTIVITY within OCCUPATION?
Answer: OCCUPATION with a SIGNIFICANTACTIVITY tag, since exhibiting suggests notable investment of energy.
